title: At Fundraiser, Trump Praises ‘Tremendous’ Kavanaugh, Claims Upper Hand on Trade
authors: Michael C. Bender, Byron Tau, Mike.Bender Wsj.Com, Byron.Tau Wsj.Com
content:
WASHINGTON—President Trump praised the performance of his Supreme Court nominee , joked about a supporter ’ s divorce and claimed the upper hand in the trade negotiations with Canada during an 80-minute , campaign-style speech he delivered Thursday night at a private fundraiser , according to people who attended the event .
Described by attendees as energized and enthusiastic , the president arrived late to the party inside a ballroom at his Washington hotel , then delivered a lengthy speech in front of 300 people , including about 100 U.S. House members . The event raised $ 15 million for a joint fundraising committee that included the National Republican Congressional Committee and the Protect the House political committee , House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy told the group .
Mr. Trump polled his crowd on Judge Brett Kavanaugh ’ s performance at a day-long Senate Judiciary Committee hearing , telling supporters that he thought it was “ tremendous. ” Mr. Trump said he loved the nominee ’ s aggressive opening statement and felt good about the chances for confirmation , attendees said .
“ What they ’ re doing to him and his family is vicious , ” Mr. Trump said , according to a person who was present .
The president zeroed in on the moment during the opening statement when Mr. Kavanaugh choked up talking about how his 10-year-old daughter wanted to pray for Christine Blasey Ford , who has accused Mr. Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct . The president described the moment as powerful and emotional , adding that it was “ hard to watch . ”
Mr. Trump said Mr. Kavanaugh ’ s confirmation will come down to a handful of senators , whom he did not name . The president may have been referring to Republican Sens . Jeff Flake of Arizona , Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine , who have either said they are undecided or have n't commented .
“ It ’ s up to three people , and they ’ ve got to do the right thing , ” the president said , according to a person who was present .
On trade , Mr. Trump said that Japan , Korea and China are “ shipping all of their garbage to the United States . That is why it takes so long to get here . ”
“ Here ’ s a little secret—it ’ s all about cars , ” Mr. Trump said about trade negotiations .
The president said that he asked Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau what would happen if the U.S. put 20 % tariffs on Canada , adding that 25 % would be “ cruel . ”
“ And do you know what Justin said ? He said , ‘ We ’ d be sunk , ’ ” Mr. Trump said .
The Canadian embassy didn ’ t immediately return a request for comment .
Mr. Trump pointed out several of the attendees , including House Speaker Paul Ryan . “ The fake news will tell you how much I hate Paul Ryan , but Paul , you ’ ve been great , ” Mr. Trump said , according to people in the room . “ Haven ’ t you been great ? ”
The biggest laugh of the night , according to one attendee , was when Mr. Trump joked about a divorce settlement involving oil billionaire Harold Hamm , who attended the event . “ What ’ d she get ? Like $ 900 million ? ” Mr. Trump said , eliciting a roar from the crowd .
Mr. Trump covered a broad range of topics in his speech , running through a list of positive economic statistics , claiming victories in trade negotiations and the upper hand in foreign policy disputes , attendees said .
“ It was a good campaign message to hear , ” said Rep. Jeff Duncan ( R. , S.C. ) .
Mr. Trump also spent several minutes talking about Saudi Arabia , focusing on the wealth in the country— “ They don ’ t know what poor is , ” he said—and adding he would never bow to the Saudi leaders .
“ They tell me , ‘ Mr . Trump , it ’ s protocol. ’ I said , ‘ I ’ m not going to do it—I ’ m not going to bow , ’ ” Mr. Trump said .
Mr. Trump said he also told Saudi King Salman that had it not been for the U.S. , “ Iran would have taken them over a long time ago . ”
The president ’ s performance was described as entertaining by many in the room , some of whom said they had paid $ 30,000 to attend .
content_original:
WASHINGTON—President Trump praised the performance of his Supreme Court nominee, joked about a supporter’s divorce and claimed the upper hand in the trade negotiations with Canada during an 80-minute, campaign-style speech he delivered Thursday night at a private fundraiser, according to people who attended the event.

Described by attendees as energized and enthusiastic, the president arrived late to the party inside a ballroom at his Washington hotel, then delivered a lengthy speech in front of 300 people, including about 100 U.S. House members. The event raised $15 million for a joint fundraising committee that included the National Republican Congressional Committee and the Protect the House political committee, House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy told the group.

Mr. Trump polled his crowd on Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s performance at a day-long Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, telling supporters that he thought it was “tremendous.” Mr. Trump said he loved the nominee’s aggressive opening statement and felt good about the chances for confirmation, attendees said.

“What they’re doing to him and his family is vicious,” Mr. Trump said, according to a person who was present.

Related Video At Thursday’s Senate hearing, Judge Brett Kavanaugh gets emotional as he recounts moments that involved his family and friends. Photo: Associated Press

The president zeroed in on the moment during the opening statement when Mr. Kavanaugh choked up talking about how his 10-year-old daughter wanted to pray for Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused Mr. Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct. The president described the moment as powerful and emotional, adding that it was “hard to watch.”

Mr. Trump said Mr. Kavanaugh’s confirmation will come down to a handful of senators, whom he did not name. The president may have been referring to Republican Sens. Jeff Flake of Arizona, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine, who have either said they are undecided or haven't commented.

“It’s up to three people, and they’ve got to do the right thing,” the president said, according to a person who was present.

On trade, Mr. Trump said that Japan, Korea and China are “shipping all of their garbage to the United States. That is why it takes so long to get here.”

“Here’s a little secret—it’s all about cars,” Mr. Trump said about trade negotiations.

The president said that he asked Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau what would happen if the U.S. put 20% tariffs on Canada, adding that 25% would be “cruel.”

“And do you know what Justin said? He said, ‘We’d be sunk,’ ” Mr. Trump said.

The Canadian embassy didn’t immediately return a request for comment.

Related Video Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused him of sexual assault, Thursday testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee. Here are some key moments. Photo: Getty Images.

Mr. Trump pointed out several of the attendees, including House Speaker Paul Ryan. “The fake news will tell you how much I hate Paul Ryan, but Paul, you’ve been great,” Mr. Trump said, according to people in the room. “Haven’t you been great?”

The biggest laugh of the night, according to one attendee, was when Mr. Trump joked about a divorce settlement involving oil billionaire Harold Hamm, who attended the event. “What’d she get? Like $900 million?” Mr. Trump said, eliciting a roar from the crowd.

Mr. Trump covered a broad range of topics in his speech, running through a list of positive economic statistics, claiming victories in trade negotiations and the upper hand in foreign policy disputes, attendees said.

“It was a good campaign message to hear,” said Rep. Jeff Duncan (R., S.C.).

Mr. Trump also spent several minutes talking about Saudi Arabia, focusing on the wealth in the country—“They don’t know what poor is,” he said—and adding he would never bow to the Saudi leaders.

“They tell me, ‘Mr. Trump, it’s protocol.’ I said, ‘I’m not going to do it—I’m not going to bow,’ ” Mr. Trump said.

Mr. Trump said he also told Saudi King Salman that had it not been for the U.S., “Iran would have taken them over a long time ago.”

The president’s performance was described as entertaining by many in the room, some of whom said they had paid $30,000 to attend.

“That was great,” Rep. Tom Graves (R., Ga.) said.

—Reid. J. Epstein contributed to this article.

Write to Michael C. Bender at Mike.Bender@wsj.com and Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.com
